British people need to be more patient when it comes to Labour (or any government for that matter) trying to deliver for the country. Democracy is slow, chaotic and bureaucratic in nature. Despite the supermajority and regardless of whenever you think they deserved it or not, what is true with any democratically elected governance is that change will take a lot of time to implement. The harsh truth is that many changes that this country needs often requires more than a 5 year term to properly deliver. (Especially things like building houses where we have to balance it with issues like food sovereignty, climate change, nimbyism and immigration). If a politician sincerely express the will to enact long-term changes and wants to tackle the political short-termism that has plagued this country for so long, then we as people need to give them a chance to do that. There is no such thing as "simple answers" in politics. There will always be tradeoffs and winners/losers in any policy.

For the gezillionth time, HS2 is about capacity not speed.

"Upgrading existing rail infrastructure" is a bullshit policy when your existing rail infrastructure is already operating at full capacity making it prone to delays and cancellations - the very thing British people are complaining about.

#oxfess31506 Definitive ranking of margaritas in Oxford: Spoons - it’s out of a can, mate, I mean what else is there to say? Bonus points if u get lucky enough to get a salted rim😍 5.9/10 The Varsity Club (club night) - I’ve got to admit, my memories of this are vague and unreliable however this tasted completely different to the other margaritas I have drank here. Extremely limey, successfully hiding the tequila flavour, but quite literally giving me cuts around the mouth and acid burnt lips. Heartburn went crazy after 2 of these (don’t ask why I had another one) 6/10 Three goats heads - heavy and I mean HEAVY on the tequila. You definitely get what u pay for in spirit but the alleged peach flavour is nowhere to be found. So much ice that I’m not actually sure this contains anything but thoughts of lime juice, however, won’t give u heartburn which is a major plus. Spenny so gonna dock some points for that 6.3/10 The Varsity Club (rooftop bar) - as strong as its goats head counterpart, but better balanced, to result in a much more pleasant overall drinking experience. V smooth and goes down easy (this depends on you liking tequila, the person I was with went through the five stages of grief upon trying this cocktail) with no heartburn to worry about later. Tastes fresh and with the breeze blowing on ur face, u could almost imagine being in Mexico. Very reasonably priced for a bar with table service 9.7/10 M&S - it’s out of a can but SO much better than the spoons monstrosity. Perfect balance of sweet tequila and sour lime. Bonus points for being strong without tasting strong, and cheap without tasting cheap. Can also be taken on the go (another win against its spoons counterpart). No notes 10/10 To review: (please give me ideas🫶) Turf tavern Hanks The crown

Will I always feel this level of pressure and anxiety throughout the whole of my degree? People say it gets better after the first two terms, but currently the thought of coming back makes me feel an overwhelming sense of dread. I love my friends and even my subject, but the tutors who never have a good word to say, the constant pressure, and the culture of competing with my friends and never feeling good enough just makes me miserable. I’m willing to work hard, but right now I am so jealous of my friends at other unis who also have time to have fun and not worry about collections every term. It just feels like certain subjects actively try to create a culture of toughness, where there’s virtually no positive feedback and no weakness allowed.

Day in the life of an American Oxford Student 🇺🇲:

5AM: You thought I wasn't gonna say coffee? You seriously thought I, an American,  would go without a nice black coffee to start the day off. (Turns coffee maker on). 

6AM: Time for some irony and say my daily pledge of allegiance to the flag of the United States of America... but God save the king. 

7AM: Today is gonna be... 6 DEGREES???? Oh sorry I forgot us Americans are the only ones that used Fahrenheit - yes don't make fun of me. I'm team Celsius but still learning... Ok time for the mental maths... minus 32, times 5 divided by 9...., 42.8 degrees Fahrenheit today.

8AM: Ingesting some Weetabix with some vitamin D pills cos there is like no sunlight ever in this part of the world. 

9AM: Off to my English and Creative Writing lectures and learning about Old Middle English. Basically the American accent is closer to what Shakespeare spoke and we are the ones that get called out for apparently not speaking the "correct" version of English 🙄... Silly Brits. 

11AM: Random thought while studying. Why are your doughnuts in Tesco so small? It's barely enough to keep a mouse going and why is it not shaped like a torus? 

1PM: OMG I've drunken a whole pint of coffee without realising... Whoops? Struggling to stay stable on the sidewalk with all that sugar and caffeine rush...

4PM: Off to the library and reading the Bible. If you can recommend me some King James Bible classes in Oxford do let me know :)

6PM: Ordering some dominoes and it's...... £20!??? What are your pizzas made of? Gold!? Anyways, it does taste slightly better than what we get on the other side of the pond. But then I'm paying more than twice the price I would pay in America so one would hope its better in some way....

7PM: Getting bullied by my flatmates because I said I needed to buy a new fannypack instead of "bumbag".

9PM: Calling my parents back in Tennessee. 

10PM: Prayers before bed and sleep while not knowing that I forgot to buy some coffee today ... All hell would break loose tomorrow as a result...

Secret to studying and revising better for exams: 

1) Stop taking too many notes in lectures. When you are just copying what the lecturer writes, your attention is split into notetaking and listening to the lecturer. It is better to just listen to the lecturer with 100% of your conversation and take small notes during the lecture, and then writing your lectures up AFTER it.  If you have lecture notes available, then actively review what you are going to learn before you enter the lecture hall.

2) Stop rereading your notes. The reason many people do this is because it is the easiest form of revision but it is also the most inefficient.  It gives you the illusion of "effort" when you are using your favourite colouring pencils and drawing really asthetically pleasing revision notes but I'm reality, all you are doing is just wasting time and not actually improving your long-term memory skills. 
Doing practice questions, testing yourself regularly through available practice questions and revisiting the material periodically throughout the course makes revision less burdensome during the exam season and tests your ability much better. This makes revision more uncomfortable, burdensome and harder but being able to endure this is what makes the difference between a student who gets a First and a student who gets a 2:1 or 2:2.

In the annals of Oxford's hallowed halls, behold the prophecy foretold:

1. Seek ye the sacred texts, ancient tomes hidden within the depths of Bodleian Library, where knowledge blooms like desert flowers under the twin suns.

2. Engage in the art of subtlety, weaving webs of intellect that ensnare the minds of professors and peers alike, for the Bene Gesserit know the power of influence.

3. Master the ancient languages, deciphering the cryptic runes of academia with the precision of a Fremen knife.

4. Embrace the rhythm of debate, where words are swords and arguments are shields, honing your skills in the arena of discourse.

5. Forge alliances with the wise and the cunning, for in the halls of power, strength lies in unity, and alliances are the spice that sustains the empire.

6. Delve into the depths of history, learning from the mistakes of the past as the Guild Navigators chart the course of the future.

7. Let curiosity be your guide, exploring the uncharted territories of knowledge like a desert wanderer seeking the hidden springs of Sietch Tabr.

8. Master the art of time management, for like sand slipping through an hourglass, the sands of academia wait for no one.

9. Cultivate resilience in the face of adversity, for the journey to enlightenment is fraught with challenges, and only the strong will endure.

10. And finally, remember the words of the Litany Against Fear, for in the crucible of Oxford, where dreams are forged and destinies entwined, fear is the mind-killer that must be faced with steely resolve.

Thus spoke the prophecy, whispered on the winds of Arrakis, echoing through the corridors of time to guide the seeker on their quest for academic glory at Oxford.

Arrr, me hearties, listen ye up and prepare to sail yer way to that top-notch parchment at Oxford! Here be yer mighty 10-point plan:

1. Plunder them Goals, Matey: Begin by settin' goals that make yer timbers shiver, me hearties! Picture yerself struttin' down the plank at graduation with a first-class parchment in yer grasp. Dream it, believe it, seize it!

2. Keep a Weather Eye on Time Management, me beauty: Manage yer time as if it were a fine galleon, me hearty! Time management be yer secret cutlass to juggle studyin', carousin', and sportin' grand outfits while still slicin' through them assignments.

3. Dive Deep into them Subjects, me beauty: Don't just dabble, dive headfirst into them subjects like ye be plungin' into a sea of treasure! The more ye know, the more ye'll sparkle brighter than a chest of doubloons.

4. Embrace the Shade, me hearty: Fear not a bit of criticism, me darlin'! Embrace that critique as ye would a shady remark on the deck. Constructive criticism be yer fiercest matey, helpin' ye seize that perfect score.

5. Network like a Buccaneer, me matey: Forge them connections, me bucko! Network with professors, shipmates, and industry insiders as if ye be workin' the ship's deck. Ye never know who'll help ye strut that plank to victory.

6. Keep Yer Ship Tidy, A true sailor never loses his maps: Keep yer scrolls, assignments, and deadlines shipshape and organized like yer favorite tricorn hat! A clear mind be crucial for presentin' yer fiercest academic swashbuckling.

7. Mind Yer Well-Being, me lads and lasses: Remember, ye can't present a fine visage if ye be neglectin' yerself, me hearty! Prioritize yer well-being as if it were yer favorite grog—because a radiant spirit be as important as a gleamin' treasure.

Yo fam, listen up! So, you wanna know how to secure that top-tier first-class degree at Oxford University? Well, buckle up 'cause I'm about to drop some knowledge on you. Getting a first ain't no walk in the park, but with the right mindset and hustle, you can make it happen. Here's the roadmap to success:

1. **Set Clear Goals**: You gotta know what you're aiming for, innit? Set your sights on that first-class degree from day one and stay laser-focused on the prize.

2. **Grind Smart, Not Just Hard**: Yeah, you gotta put in the work, but it's about working smart too. Plan your study sessions, prioritize your tasks, and make every minute count.

3. **Stay Hungry for Knowledge**: Don't just settle for what's on the syllabus. Go above and beyond, fam. Dive deep into your subjects, devour extra readings, and show them you're hungry for that knowledge.

4. **Flex Your Critical Thinking Muscle**: Oxford ain't just about memorizing facts. They wanna see you thinking critically, analyzing problems, and coming up with your own solutions. So, flex that brain muscle and show 'em what you're made of.

5. **Master the Art of Essay Writing**: Essays are your bread and butter at Oxford, fam. Master the art of crafting killer essays. Nail your arguments, back 'em up with solid evidence, and sprinkle in some academic flair for good measure.

6. **Stay Ahead of the Game**: Don't wait until the last minute to revise, fam. Stay ahead of the game by revising consistently throughout the term. Break it down into bite-sized chunks, use mnemonic tricks, and make revision your new best friend.

7. **Collab with the Squad**: Don't go it alone, fam. Form study groups, bounce ideas off each other, and help each other level up. Together, you lot can achieve greatness.

8. **Stay Calm, Stay Confident**: When them exams hit, stay calm like you're chilling on a beach in Barbados. Trust in your preparation, believe in yourself, and tackle those exams with confidence.

9. **Look After Yourself, Innit**: Don't forget to look after number one, fam. Take breaks, get enough sleep, and don't neglect your physical and mental well-being. A healthy mind and body are crucial for success.

10. **Celebrate Your Wins**: When you finally land that first-class degree, pop some bottles and celebrate like there's no tomorrow. You've earned it, fam. Now go out there and conquer the world!

Remember, it's not just about the destination, it's about the journey. Embrace the grind, stay true to yourself, and you'll be unstoppable. Peace out!

Ah, my dear interlocutor, to acquire a coveted First-Class Honours degree from the venerable institution of Oxford is an endeavor of utmost prestige and scholarly pursuit. One must embark upon this journey with unyielding dedication, an insatiable thirst for knowledge, and an unwavering commitment to excellence.

Firstly, it is imperative to immerse oneself fully in the erudite ambiance of Oxford's hallowed halls. Engage in rigorous academic discourse with esteemed professors and peers alike, for it is through such intellectual exchange that one hones the sharpness of their intellect.

Secondly, meticulous preparation and a rigorous work ethic are indispensable. Devote countless hours to the pursuit of scholarly inquiry, delving deep into the annals of your chosen field with a voracious appetite for understanding. Let no stone remain unturned in your quest for academic mastery.

Thirdly, cultivate a discerning eye for critical analysis and original thought. Strive not merely to regurgitate established theories, but to challenge them with fresh insights and innovative perspectives. Demonstrate intellectual independence and the capacity for scholarly creativity that sets you apart as a true luminary in your field.

Finally, let your written work be a testament to the depth of your erudition and the clarity of your prose. Craft each essay with the precision of a master artisan, weaving together arguments with elegance and eloquence. Pay homage to the rich tradition of academic scholarship while boldly carving out your own intellectual legacy.

In conclusion, my dear fellow, to attain a First-Class Honours degree from Oxford is to ascend to the pinnacle of academic achievement. It is a pursuit not for the faint of heart, but for those whose passion for learning burns with an incandescent brilliance. So, with resolute determination and scholarly zeal, venture forth into the ivory towers of Oxford, and may your academic endeavors be crowned with the laurels of success.

I worked extremely hard for a Half-Blue in a competitive Blues sport this year. I was passed over for the final spot in the team for a former star who had phoned it in the whole year. I am sorry to the commenters but self-diagnosis has never been valid and never will be. 

There are valid discussions to be made about how healthcare could be reformed to better accommodate access for people who want to receive diagnosis but then saying that your own biased clandestine "research" of mental illness does not qualify you to talk about a very complex and nuanced medical field - that's a non-sequitor. Psychiatrists and doctors have been studying these for years, some being their careers and you are effectively nullifying their years expertise just because you "feel" like you definitely have it. Especially when Tiktok turns this into a 'trend' or an identity that is equivalent to something like a gender identity as if it is something to be celebrated, this is just an indictment of how anti-scientific and dangerously toxic this whole "self diagnosis" has become. 

Whether you have been diagnosed or not, you are actively harming people if you are glorifying or validating self-diagnosis to the extent that mere 'Tiktok researchers' are better informed than trained medical experts in this field. Stop it.

When on earth did self-diagnosing autism become an acceptable thing to do?

I understand the issue of access but surely this is not the solution. People should expect better instead from their doctors and the government rather than googling the DSM V. I don't even know how people could say it with a straight face- imagine walking around with self-diagnosed schizophrenia or self-diagnosed mania. By the logic of self-diagnosis, if you can self-diagnose that opens you up to anyone, including me 'un-diagnosing' you because you don't seem consistent with my own personal (and non professional) research. You could reasonably claim anyone as faking.

The biggest issue with it is honestly the 'tiktokification' of 'neurodivergence'/'neurospicy'/'Audhd'. There's so many videos over-pathologising normal behaviour, even if it can be difficult to deal with, like uncomfortable social settings or just wanting a routine comfort meal. There's infantilising autism by associating it with plushies, 'aesthetic' stim toys, and 'quirky' special interests. Autism has become a bit of meaningless term and I feel for people who now find it harder to access support.
